text.content: : Find groups of n digits, but no more than n.

rich_text.plain_text: : Find groups of n digits, but no more than n.

text.content:
# Using Extended regular expressions (by -E flag)
grep -E '(^|[^0-9])[0-9]{4}($|[^0-9])' file

rich_text.plain_text:

text.content: : Enclose the first letter of every word in a sentence inside round brackets.

rich_text.plain_text: : Enclose the first letter of every word in a sentence inside round brackets.

text.content:
echo "Apples are good for health" | sed 's/\(\b[A-Z]\)/\(\1\)/g'

# Output
(A)pples (a)re (g)ood (f)or (h)ealth

text.content: Â utility is used to execute programs written in the awk programming language which is specialized for textual data manipulation. It's a sequence of patterns and corresponding actions. When an input is discovered matching a pattern, the associated action is carried out.

rich_text.plain_text: Â utility is used to execute programs written in the awk programming language which is specialized for textual data manipulation. It's a sequence of patterns and corresponding actions. When an input is discovered matching a pattern, the associated action is carried out.

text.content: Input is always taken as a line unless otherwise specified.

rich_text.plain_text: Input is always taken as a line unless otherwise specified.

text.content: (a) Scans a file line by line(b) Splits each input line into fields(c) Compares input line/fields to pattern(d) Performs action(s) on matched lines

text.content: : Let's say if you wish to remove inactive replica sets in a Kubernetes cluster.

rich_text.plain_text: : Let's say if you wish to remove inactive replica sets in a Kubernetes cluster.

text.content: Â prints this to the terminal -

rich_text.plain_text: Â prints this to the terminal -

text.content:
$ kubectl get all | grep replicaset.apps
NAME                                           DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/limosyn-com-ghost-6d47f4c9b9   1         1         1       7d9h
replicaset.apps/limosyn-com-mysql-dffbd7cdb    1         1         1       7d9h
replicaset.apps/nuxt-frontend-546dff5b99       1         1         1       7d2h
replicaset.apps/nuxt-frontend-67f5659d95       0         0         0       7d8h


# Delete the 4th replica
$ kubectl delete $(kubectl get all | grep replicaset.apps | awk '{if ($2 + $3 + $4 == 0) print $1}')

rich_text.plain_text:
$ kubectl get all | grep replicaset.apps
NAME                                           DESIRED   CURRENT   READY   AGE
replicaset.apps/limosyn-com-ghost-6d47f4c9b9   1         1         1       7d9h
replicaset.apps/limosyn-com-mysql-dffbd7cdb    1         1         1       7d9h
replicaset.apps/nuxt-frontend-546dff5b99       1         1         1       7d2h
replicaset.apps/nuxt-frontend-67f5659d95       0         0         0       7d8h


# Delete the 4th replica
$ kubectl delete $(kubectl get all | grep replicaset.apps | awk '{if ($2 + $3 + $4 == 0) print $1}')

text.content: Â - Case insensitive comparison of lines

rich_text.plain_text: Â - Case insensitive comparison of lines

text.content: Â - Check the order of the input, even if all input lines are pairable.

rich_text.plain_text: Â - Check the order of the input, even if all input lines are pairable.

text.content:
$ cat words.txt
Apple
Banana
Orange
India
US
Canada

$ cat countries.txt
India
US
Canada

$ comm -23 < (sort words.txt | uniq) < (sort countries.txt | uniq)
Apple
Banana
Orange

Banana
Orange
India
US
Canada

$ cat countries.txt

Canada

$ comm -23 < (sort words.txt | uniq) < (sort countries.txt | uniq)

Banana

text.content: So here we are at the end of this article. I have purposefully not included a lot of information for each command. You are better off referring to the documentation that I added to each of them. Â My goal is to make you aware of such commands so that you don't always need to resort to scripting languages such as Python or Perl.

text.content: If you are a DevOps Engineer like me, you'd surely be required to set up certain event-triggered automation/cron jobs which are mostly written in shell. Knowing some advanced commands like above is certainly priceless.
